posts.content:
The Eternal Elven Spellblade



There's been quite a bit of interest in Spellswords lately, and I thought I would try my hand at making my own. 

This I thought might be the Spellsword build I want to play, particularly on a persistent world which has challenges well beyond level 40. 

Cool features:

- 4 attacks per round, AB 38 with mundane greatsword, AC 32 with mundane plate
- Base Strength 28, base Devastating Critical DC 39, Weapon Specialisation + Epic Weapon Specialisation Greatsword
- Improved Knockdown (for casters) and Improved Disarm (for situational AB increases)

- Up to level 9 wizard spells plus Epic Warding, Epic Mage Armor, Scribe Scroll, Still spell and Extended spell
- Time Stop / Devastating Critical Combo

- Over 400 natural hp 
- Critical hit immunity, Sneak attack immunity, Stun/Paralysis/Hold immunity

- About 250 skill points, allowing maxed Discipline, maxed Concentration, essentially max Listen and Spellcraft and at least 20 crossclass ranks in Tumble and Search, Heal 15 modified to cure pretty much all all disease/poison outside of combat 
- Elven Keen senses to make the most of Listen and Search skills

- No exp penalties

Downsides:

- 7 caster levels meaning dispellable buffs (except EW/EMA) and difficulties with spell penetration

- I think AB is adequate to hit things but maybe some of you know better than me. If I add more pre-epic fighter levels I seem to lose level 9 wizard spells, so I've left it as it is

Other F/W/PM builds:

There are 12 F/W/PM builds I can find in the archives. The closest to my build is Mithdradates's Soldier of Death, Grizzled_Dwarflord's Deathless Pariah and Deadmoney9951's Undead Spellsword. 

Soldier of Death has Devastating Critical but only up to level 6 wizard spells. Deathless Pariah and Undead Spellsword don't get Devastating Critical because they focus on getting Automatic Still Spell III (which I feel uncomfortable with, with only 10-18 caster levels and an attribute modifier of 4-5).

So this could be a new build with the class combos, elven race etc...

Automatic Still Spell III is not required to cast Time Stop consistently in Full Plate:

One cool thing I learnt is that Time Stop has no somatic component, it is only verbal. That means that Arcane Spell failure from armor doesn't apply. That means Automatic Still Spell III is not required to cast Time Stop in Full Plate (+ Tower), and I've tested this in game!

Time Stop / Devastating Critical combo: 

Sometimes I wish my high strength fighter could cast Time Stop in combat and land a nice Devastating Critical on a difficult opponent

Here's a nice screenshot of my Spellblade doing that in the PGCC module with a Mundane Greatsword and Mundane Fullplate as the only items equipped:


What do you think? Any improvements you can think of?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Oh, she looks mighty fine for a first attempt, it shows you have done some serious studying beforehand.

Jeez, I just woke up so, take what I say with a grain of salt...

You want Improvements? Alright.
a) Change race to Dwarf. Go with Str18(30) Dex8 Con14 Int16(19) Wis8 Cha6.
Same hit points, better strength, better Dev Crit, better AB, better Dmg, better saves Vs spells. I know, I Know...you can keep the same photo of her, if that makes you feel better.
b) Check Wizard bonus feats, if you can take EMA with them, then switch to (Ftr 14/ Wiz 10/ PM 16) to gain 3 "real" CL.
c) You have plenty of skill points so, give him deadly traps, the more tools - the better. You do not need so many detection stuff with TS around.
d) Dont concern yourself too much with Auto Still 3, for WoG. Just use the FG's chain-shirt & shield bracers & you'll be (more than) fine.
e) Get Dev Crit earlier, you can do it.
st) IDS is nice but not so nice as Empower spell.
f) See, if you can play an Illusionist for more spell-power. They lose some spells but nothing critically important.

Gotta get some coffee...

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Thanks Valerfor for the advice, pretty much everything you have written I agree with.

I have checked the bonus wizard feats and unfortunately I don't think I can take EMA with them. No matter though, EMA I feel unsure about, mostly because of this comment in the NWN Wiki:
https://nwn.fandom.com/wiki/Epic_mage_armor wrote:

This spell often has no effect other than the +5 dodge bonus, due to epic characters frequently possessing +5 or better equipment. However, a character who polymorphs after casting this spell usually benefits from the full +20 as item bonuses are lost during arcane polymorphs.
So I dropped it and 3 pale master levels for empower spell and extra caster levels (to help the buffs last longer). Also I discovered it allows me to cast two level 9 spells / day (meaning two, [three? time stop casts / day if I also specialise in illusionist?] as you wrote, instead of one cast / day) which I think is definitely worth dropping EMA, and a few rounds of duration on EW.

Got Str 30, AB 40!!!! (hooray!), devastating critical at level 30 (rather than 40!) and kept improved disarm too. Dropped epic weapon specialisation to get AB 40 from epic prowess, but I think I would prefer to make sure I hit them and critical them 5% more often, than do +4 damage per hit and hit them less.

Managed to also keep improved disarm in the build, this guy is meant to be a mean killer and it could be situationally useful, particularly against enemies with tiny (daggers) or small weapons (short swords)

Anyway its a dwarf now and I can't keep the same picture, so lets make a new build...

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
A crit. immune dev. crit. build is always scary. Now give it lvl 9 arcane spellpower and epic spells...

(OK, so the caster level is low with short duration and limited power of many spells. The spell penetration and spells DC are awful. But that is not important here, because your focus lies elsewhere.)

Bottom line: I like the build!

Edit: If you take Set trap, it is very convenient to have at least 1 point in disarm traps. Just so you can pick up (recover) traps you want to move to a better location, and any leftover traps that didn't go off during the fight. You always have automatic success when you recover your own traps, but you need the skill to be able to do it.

posts.author: Aquarius 233
posts.content:
I like the build!
I am considering it as a way to open up my mind and discover "neutral/evil" classes, as up to now I have never considered them due to the alignment (cannot act as an evil PC).

Just a question:
the nwn wiki for palemasters says that "He does not learn any new spells through this ability, but for wizards it can allow higher-level spells to be learned through other means (i.e. from scrolls or later leveling as a wizard).".

I'll put it as an example to be clearer:
With a 5 level wizard, I have one lv 3 slot. If I proceed with PM until W5/PM3, the lv 3 slots become 2, plus a lv 4 spell slot.
If I do not have scrolls at my disposal, the only thing to be done is to level up as a wiz at 9 level: that way, I can select both lv 4 spells and lv 3 spells that I should have acquired if I had previously leveled up as a wiz instead of a PM.

Can you confirm?

The same, I think, applies to sorcerers. This should clear why the latest illusionist levels are chosen after the PM ones.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Orion, I'm thinking (now that I had a couple of coffees at last) that you don't really lose anything by stoping PM progression at 12th-level (Ch. level-thirty) & taking asap the rest of wizard levels in order to get empower spell at 34th-level instead of 39th, right? The reasoning for this are some especially annoying melee enemies that might need gms/igms & then empowered gms/igms (double the firepower, essentially). Then you continue with the rest of the PM levels as planned, leaving last your fighter level & epic prowess. Now, you do delay the epic warding a bit, but this still should be a better trade overall.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Aquarius you are very insightful and correct. 

Pale Master doesn't learn any new spells, only gets access to the spell slots of a higher level, so those extra spells slots will need to be learned through scrolls. 

I took the Wizard levels at the end to get Epic Warding ASAP. A side effect was to also obtain Time Stop/Mords for free without relying on finding a Time Stop or Mord's Scroll. 

I haven't had a single Time Stop or Mord's scroll drop during my playthrough as Druid to level 40 on WoG, so I wanted to guarantee access to both spells when this character hits level 38, by taking those last levels of Wizard late and making sure the character has a base intelligence of 19 (hence the Great Intelligence feat taken at Wizard 5 rather than Empower Spell) when those levels are taken. 

It's just a bias I have, to reduce reliance on the environment for a critical power spike. Both Time Stop and Mord's are verbal only spells without somatic components, so they both should be able to be cast in full plate (I have tested Time Stop, haven't tested Mord's yet).

I take Valerfor's point though. In an environment where Time Stop and Mord scrolls are accessible I would definitely swap the Great Int and Empower Spell bonus wizard feats around. Originally I made the build that way but swapped them around to secure those spells without relying on the environment. That way Epic Warding stays where it is and Empowered ILMS and IGMS can be cast, if necessary, (or Empowered Bulls Strength / Endurance / Cat's Grace etc )
